payload.title: Arriving at KLIA/KLIA2
payload.description: Kuala Lumpur has two main terminals: **KLIA (Terminal 1)** for full-service carriers and **KLIA2 (Terminal 2)** for budget airlines like AirAsia. Both are connected to the city via the high-speed rail.
payload.criticalAlert: You **must** complete the **Malaysia Digital Arrival Card (MDAC)** online within 3 days before your arrival. It is free, but mandatory for all foreigners (except Singaporeans).
tips: **KLIA Ekspres:** The fastest way into the city. Use the app or website to buy tickets for a 10% discount compared to the counter.
**Grab Pickup:** Download the Grab app. At both terminals, you must head to the designated 'Transportation Hub' (Level 1) for app pickups.
**Tolls:** If taking a car, expect to pay around RM10 in tolls. Drivers will add this to your fare; it's standard procedure.
**Biometric Gates:** On your second visit to Malaysia, you can often use the automated 'E-Gates' if you registered your biometrics on the first trip.

payload.title: QR Codes & Touch 'n Go
payload.description: KL is a leader in QR payments (DuitNow). While Visa/Mastercard work in malls, the city's transit and small stalls require specialized payment methods.
payload.criticalAlert: You **cannot** tap your foreign credit card directly at LRT/MRT gates. You must buy a physical **Touch 'n Go (TNG) card** or a single-trip token (cash/card at machines).
tips: **TNG eWallet:** If you have an Asian phone number, setting up the Touch 'n Go eWallet is a superpower. It is accepted at almost every night market stall (Jalan Alor).
**DuitNow QR:** If you have a banking app from Singapore (PayLah!), Thailand, or Indonesia, you can scan Malaysian DuitNow QR codes directly.
**Cash Stash:** Keep RM50–100 in small notes (RM1, RM5) for 'Mamak' stalls and public restrooms.

payload.title: Safety & Local Advice
payload.description: KL is safe, but traffic and humidity are your biggest enemies. Petty 'snatch theft' by motorbikes is the most common crime to watch for.
payload.criticalAlert: Avoid walking with your phone or bag on the 'roadside' of the sidewalk. Motorbike snatch thefts can happen quickly in busy areas like Bukit Bintang.
tips: **Taxi Meter Scam:** If a taxi driver at a tourist spot refuses the meter and quotes a flat price, use **Grab** instead. It's almost always cheaper and safer.
**Dress Code:** When visiting Batu Caves, both men and women must cover their knees. You can rent a sarong at the bottom for RM5.
**Monsoon Awareness:** Heavy rain usually hits in the late afternoon (3 PM–5 PM). Plan your indoor mall visits or museum trips for this window.
